questions.text: Quincke’s sign is characteristic of chronic, severe AR. Which of the following is true about this sign?

options.label: A
options.text: To-and-fro murmur audible if the femoral artery is lightly compressed with a stethoscope.

options.label: B
options.text: Capillary pulsations, an alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail

options.label: C
options.text: A booming “pistol-shot” sound can be heard over the femoral arteries

questions.correct_answer: B. Capillary pulsations, an alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Capillary pulsations, an alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail A rapidly rising “water-hammer” pulse, which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole (Corrigan’s pulse), and capillary pulsations, an alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail (Quincke’s pulse), are characteristic of chronic severe AR.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Duroziez’s sign. Option: C: Traube’s sign Option: D: de Musset’s sign.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with acute, severe AR. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgery within 24 hours Patients with acute severe AR may respond to intravenous diuretics and vasodilators (such as sodium nitroprusside), but stabilisation is usually short-lived and operation is indicated urgently. Surgery is the treatment of choice and is usually necessary within 24 h of diagnosis. Intraaortic balloon counterpulsation is contraindicated. Beta blockers are also best avoided so as not to reduce the CO further or slow the heart rate, thus allowing more time for diastolic filling of the LV

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A : Stabilization is usually short-lived and operation is indicated urgently. Option: C: Intra Aortic balloon counter pulsation is contraindicated. Option: D: Beta blockers are also best avoided so as not to reduce the CO further or slow the heart rate, thus allowing more time for diastolic filling of the LV.

Extraedge:

Acute aortic regurgitation Chronic aortic regurgitation Acute rheumatic fever Rheumatic heart disease Infective endocarditis Syphilis Dissection of the aorta Arthritides: Reiter's syndrome Ankylosing spondylitis Rheumatoid arthritis Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm Hypertension (severe) Failure of prosthetic valve Bicuspid aortic valve Aortic endocarditis Marfan's syndrome Osteogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: Which of the conditions can cause the murmur as depicted below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AS The image shows a murmur which begins after S1 and ends before S2-it is a midsystolic murmur AS is the most common cause of mid systolic murmur in an adult. So , Option A , C and D are not the correct choices.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A , B .-The murmur occurs during acute rheumatic fever due to mitral valvulitis which causes thickening of the leaflets and a diastolic murmur is created due to the blood flow across a thickened mitral valve. It can be differentiated from MDM of MS by the fact that there is no associated opening snap or pre systolic accentuation Option C -Austin flint murmur is an MDM associated with AR.

Extraedge:

Mammary souffle is an innocent continuous murmur heard over breast in pregnancy. Venous hum is heard in pregnancy at the right supra clavicular area.

questions.text: A professional football player was debarred from continuing to play due to a finding detected on routine screening echocardiography. He approached his local physician who detected a high pitched mid systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border which increases with valsalva maneuver and on standing. What is the condition he is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HOCM Effects of physiological or pharmacological interventions on murmurs: Right-sided murmurs and sounds increase during inspiration except for the pulmonary ejection click which decreases during inspiration. Left-sided murmurs/sounds –increase during expiration. Pulmonary ejection click is the only right side event that increases on expiration. Valsalva maneuver-most murmurs decrease in length and intensity except murmur of HOCM and MVP.

Highyeild:

Positional changes:- With standing most murmurs decrease except HOCM and MVP. With squatting most murmurs increase except HOCM and MVP. So, Option B , C and D can not be the right answer.

questions.text: A 41 year old female who is a known case of RHD- severe MR + moderate MS now presents with a history of fever since the last 2 weeks. On examination she is found to have splenomegaly and a new regurgitant murmur can be heard on auscultation at the apex. Echo was done and Blood cultures were drawn to confirm diagnosis. This condition is most commonly caused by :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Staphylococcus aureus The diagnosis is Endocarditis. Most common organism is Staphylococcus aureus. So Option A , B and D are not the correct option.

Highyeild:

Etiology – a. Native valve endocarditis: Mitral valve is the most common valve involved. Causative organism i. Most common cause in native valve = Staph aureus ii. Streptococci viridans iii. Streptococcus bovis (Polyp, colon tumors) iv. Enterococci v. HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) b. Prosthetic valve endocarditis (Most common valve involved is aortic valve) i. Within 2 months of surgery = staph aureus ii. After 2 months of surgery = coagulase negative staphylococci (CoNS). iii. >12 months – Streptococcus viridans c. Endocarditis in I.V. drug abusers (Most common valve involved is = tricuspid)

questions.text: A 60 year old male came to the casualty with complaints of breathlessness and chest pain. On examination ,there is presence of murmur that decreases in intensity on valsalva maneuver. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic stenosis Maneuvers Most murmurs will increase or decrease in volume when the patient performs certain maneuvers. This dynamic quality of murmurs is used as a clinical tool during the patient's physical exam to aid in diagnosing a specific murmur. Some examples of how maneuvers change the intensity of particular murmurs include: Aortic stenosis:in case of valsalva maneuver,there is decrease in preload which decreases the murmur intensity.hence the above case of aortic stenosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy:in this case,the intensity of valsalva increases,hence it is not the case of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. Option B. Mitral valve prolapse:in this case,the intensity of valsalva increases,hence it is not the case of mitral valve prolapse. Option C. Aortic stenosis:in case of valsalva maneuver,there is decrease in preload which decreases the murmur intensity.hence the above case of aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not produce a systolic murmur?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitral stenosis Mitral stenosis produces a mid diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation. Causes of systolic murmurs: Option A -Mid Systolic : AS, PS Option B - severe anemia Option C Early systolic : Acute MR, Muscular VSD Late Systolic : MVP, TVP Holosystolic : Chronic MR/TR, VSD

Highyeild:

Mid Systolic : AS, PS severe anemia Early systolic : Acute MR, Muscular VSD Late Systolic : MVP, TVP

questions.text: All are correct regarding continuous murmurs, except:

options.label: C
options.text: Heard in both systole and diastole

questions.correct_answer: D. Seen in AR with AS
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seen in AR with AS Continuous murmurs are characterized by a pressure gradient between two cardiac chambers that persists in systole and diastole. The murmur starts in systole, peaks at or around S2, and continues through some duration in diastole.

Extraedge:

Causes of continuous murmurs are- -Patent ductus arteriosus Ruptured sinus of Valsalva Coarctation of aorta (due to enlarged collateral circulation) Venous hum AR with AS (option d) causes a combination of two murmurs that is audible across systole and diastole, but does not peak in systole. Hence all the options are correct except option D.
